items.title: feat: pam_u2f add user options

items.content_html:
Description of changes

with epub manuals stubbed we can actually remove docbook from the nixos manual. nixos manual renders the same except for the option that went away, nixpkgs manual renders the same except for a few function doc items that changed. we'll keep docbook options export alive for a while since there are users of it out there, but we should remove it soon to ease the maintenance burden on nixos-render-docs keeping docbook around without using it creates.

since we don't support docbook rendering any more we can also simplify the manual rendering ci jobs, and drop the rendering equality check completely.

items.title: nixos/doc: dedocbookify

items.content_html:
We use postgres quite a bit and upgrading from old (possibly removed) versions has proven to be too manual.

The goal here is to automate the pg_upgrade process to ease postgres version changes.

Description of changes

This adds upgradeFrom and analyzeAfterUpgrade options to services.postgresql.

upgradeFrom is used to specify a list of postgres packages to upgrade. For example:

config.services.postgresql.package = pkgs.postgresql_15;

config.services.postgresql.upgradeFrom = [
  { package = pkgs.postgresql_11; dataDir = "/var/lib/postgresql/11.1"; }
  { package = pkgs.postgresql_12; dataDir = "/var/lib/postgresql/12"; }
  { package = pkgs.postgresql_14; dataDir = "/var/lib/postgresql/14"; }
];

It will try to upgrade from 11.1 to 15, then 12 -> 15, 14 ->15.
If If any of the old data dirs is either missing or marked as upgraded, the upgrade script is noop.
It it find 2 "ready to upgrade" data dir, this script will fail. You can only run pg_upgrade once, second run will fail saying the DB is initialized.

The packages are required since pg_upgrade requires paths to old binaries.

When specified, analyzeAfterUpgrade will run vacuumdb --all --analyze-in-stages as postgres suggests when pg_upgrade is done.

Comes with accompanying nixos test.

items.content_html:
This reverts commit ba3d0f7 from #235365

This change breaks gitea for configurations where PostgreSQL is not running on the same machine. It was not necessary anyway so I opted for simply reverting this change. It is also broken on 23.05.

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Add support for managing hooks via the nixos/libvirtd module.

This PR adds the virtualisation.libvirtd.hooks options for daemon/qemu/lxc/libxl/network hooks.
It also add a test checking if the qemu hook is correctly added and ran.

items.content_html:
Description of changes

This is something I had on my list for a while.

udevRulesFor generates a lot of warnings like:

substituteStream(): WARNING: pattern '"/sbin/modprobe' doesn't match anything
in file '/nix/store/.../95-dm-notify.rules'

due to the (preemptive) substitution of common paths in the default udev rules.
In this case a file having no matches is not unepected and poses no issue at
all.

Things done

items.title: nixos/devpi-server: init

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Now that Memtest86+ supports UEFI and the 64-bit Linux boot handover protocol, we can use that on UEFI systems instead of falling back to the proprietary Passmark Memtest86.

GRUB2 no longer needs any special handling for booting memtest86+ on UEFI systems, as it can be booted both using the 64-bit Linux handover protocol on UEFI and 16-bit Linux handover on legacy systems.

This allows for a better implementation than #225616 for GRUB2, because we don't need any special handling for UEFI anymore, it can use the same entry/binary as legacy boot, and still accept boot params in UEFI.

On systemd-boot we need to use the new UEFI binary as in #225616.

items.content_html:
Description of changes

This change fixes the credentialsFile injection that used install to chown settings.json file (note that chown syscall is filtered in systemd service configuration). This operation doesnt really make sense and under normal circumstances systemd should change ownership for state directories.

https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/systemd.exec.html#RuntimeDirectory=

If the specified directories already exist and their owning user or
group do not match the configured ones, all files and directories below
the specified directories as well as the directories themselves will
have their file ownership recursively changed to match what is
configured.

In addition to that, this change fixes inconsistent variable escaping in scripts, and allows using credentialsFile that is not owned by the transmission user/group.

items.title: nixos/transmission: fix credentialsFile injection

items.content_html:
Motivation for this change

If the user wants to rollback to any of the system generations but the last, this is currently not easily doable (see #24374).
In order to unify the interface with nix-env a bit more, I propose to add a flag ``nixos-rebuild --generation` to easily go to a specific generation.

I had an issue, where I didn't notice a package breaking ~10 generations ago and while fixing it, I had to go back and forth multiple times. Since I didn't know about

sudo nix-env --switch-generation 12345 -p /nix/var/nix/profiles/system
sudo /nix/var/nix/profiles/system/bin/switch-to-configuration switch

I repeated the rollback n times.

This implementation would make it possible to run

sudo nixos-rebuild switch --generation 12345

In addition this implements nixos-rebuild list-generations which shows a comprehensive overview of the available generations, including details like build-date, NixOS version, kernel and configuration revision (which can be set to the flake commit with adding modules = [ ... { system.configurationRevision = if self ? rev then self.rev else "dirty"; } ]; to the flake.nix-file).

Please note that I only started with NixOS 3 months ago, so make sure to review the changes. I followed the --rollback option, since they seem to be very simiar in what should be done

Maintainers

@nbp added --rollback
@worldofpeace did the last edits
And I guess @edolstra ?

Things done
  • Tested manually on local system
  • Ensured that relevant documentation is up to date
  • Fits CONTRIBUTING.md.
items.title: nixos:nixos-rebuild: improve generation interaction

items.content_html:
Description of changes

cage has a bunch of configuration options via environment, so add a simple extraEnvironment variable that maps to the systemd unit.

Also, set WLR_LIBINPUT_NO_DEVICES to 1 by default. This allows launching without any input devices, which I believe makes sense for a kiosk system.

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Hi, I think it should be a saner default to clean /tmp/ upon boot. Systemd should have /tmp/ as a tmpfs, so users are used to have a clean /tmp. On NixOS, with nix using /tmp/ to build, it make sense to not use tmpfs, but it should be cleaned regularly, every boot seems fine to me.

Any use case that would require to keep this disabled by default?

Would this require a release note entry?
